prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would. If 52 cards are dealt to 8 people as evenly as possible, how many people will end up with fewer than 7 cards?
solution: When you divide 52 by 8, you get 6 with a remainder of 4.  Therefore, 4 of the people will get an extra card, bringing their total to 7, while the remaining $\boxed{4}$ people have only 6 cards.
gpt_response: Let's count together to figure this out! If we have 52 cards and 8 friends, we can share them out evenly. Let's see... If we give each friend 7 cards, that's 56 cards in total. But we only have 52 cards, so we need to give each friend 6 cards instead. That means all our friends will end up with 6 cards each. So nobody will end up with fewer than 7 cards! Yay, everyone gets lots of cards to play with!
solution_prompt: Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 4?: Let's count together to figure this out! If we have 52 cards and 8 friends, we can share them out evenly. Let's see... If we give each friend 7 cards, that's 56 cards in total. But we only have 52 cards, so we need to give each friend 6 cards instead. That means all our friends will end up with 6 cards each. So nobody will end up with fewer than 7 cards! Yay, everyone gets lots of cards to play with!
